conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, and their size and position depend on the light source's position relative to the object and surface.
Shadows A, B, C, and D are currently cast behind the objects, indicating the light source is in front of the objects.
Moving the light source forward will position it closer to the objects, affecting shadow position and size.
As the light source moves forward, shadows will shift closer to the objects due to steeper light ray angles.
The size of the shadows will decrease as the light source gets closer, resulting in steeper light ray angles.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to their respective objects.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will become smaller.
When the light source moves forward above the objects, the shadows A, B, C, and D will shift closer to the objects and become smaller.
